Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AVATOL - Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's theory of evolution explained that millions of species are related, and dealt biologists and paleontologists the enormous challenge of discovering the branching pattern of the Tree of Life. Work on this great challenge is producing a map of species-relatedness through Earth history, and answering questions such as "what is the closest relative of a species?" and "what species make important products?" To do this scientists draw on all heritable features, including genotypes (e.g., DNA) and phenotypes (e.g., anatomy). Studying phenotypes, however, has remained complicated and slow, because it has not been revolutionized by computer science and engineering innovations.

A team of biologists, computer scientists, and paleontologists will extend and adapt methods from computer vision, machine learning, crowd-sourcing and natural language processing to enable rapid and automated study of phenotypes for the Tree of Life on a vast scale. The three-year goal is to release large phenomic datasets built using new methods, and to provide the public and scientific community with tools for future work. Planned is the training of teachers and students (kindergarten - postdoctoral levels) and the engagement of "citizen scien-tists." Enormous phenomic datasets, many with images, will fill an important public interest in biodiversity and the fossil record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Measurements and observations of an organism, including its morphology, behavior, and physiology, comprise its phenotype. The overall goal of the AVATOL Next-Generation Phenomics project was to develop new methods to assemble datasets of phenotypic characters across the Tree of Life. As part of this multi-investigator, collaborative project, the Thacker lab provided the AVATOL team with data and material from the previously funded Porifera Tree of Life project, including species descriptions of sponges (phylum Porifera) based on their external morphology and internal anatomy. These morphological species descriptions form the basis of our names (or taxonomy) and classification (or systematics) of sponges. 

To accelerate our assembly of morphological datasets, we used computerized natural language processing of previously published text-based species descriptions. We conducted extensive tests of new software, including CharaParser and Extended Taxon Concept (ETC), developed by AVATOL PI Cui to extract phenotypic characters from text. To increase the efficiency of this software, we developed a controlled vocabulary of sponge anatomy and represented it as an ontology, in which each term’s relationships to other terms are clearly stated. The Porifera ontology is available to the public and can be freely downloaded and browsed in OntoBee (http://www.ontobee.org/browser/index.php?o=PORO).

This project trained six undergraduate researchers in morphological taxonomy, anatomy ontology development, and morphological systematics. Two scientific articles have been published in open-access journals.

Thacker RW, Diaz MC, Kerner A, Vignes-Lebbe R, Segerdell E, Haendel MA, Mungall CJ. 2014. The Porifera Ontology (PORO): Enhancing sponge systematics with an anatomy ontology. Journal of Biomedical Semantics 5:39. doi: 10.1186/2041-1480-5-39.

Deans AR, Lewis SE, Huala E, Anzaldo SS, Ashburner M, et al. 2015. Finding our way through phenotypes. PLoS Biology 13(1):e1002033. doi: 10.1371/journal.pbio.1002033.

Two presentations were made by undergraduates at a scientific conference (the Annual Meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology).

http://www.sicb.org/meetings/2015/schedule/abstractdetails.php?id=168

http://www.sicb.org/meetings/2015/schedule/abstractdetails.php?id=156

The Thacker Lab worked closely with the NSF-funded Phenotype Research Coordination Network (RCN) to create the Porifera ontology. The Phenotype RCN team held several workshops in which PI Thacker participated; these workshops provided advanced training for PI Thacker in the area of ontology development. PI Thacker also developed new skills in scanning electron microscopy (SEM) in collaboration with the University of Alabama at Birmingham’s SEM core facility.
